choices.text: CMV is most common of non-syndromic SNHL in children
In developing countries, primary CMV infection is more common than reactivation
Presence of virus in urine after 4 weeks is diagnostic

questions.text: Which of the following statements about congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
• CMV is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL in children.
  • In developing countries, most of the mothers are exposed to CMV and thus passive immunity is passed on the child. Most of the infections are reactivation.
  • Only 10% are symptomatic.
  • Diagnosis is usually done by viral culture in urine or saliva.

questions.text: A 4 years old boy of 15kg, 100 cm tall has blood urea 100 mg/dl and serum creatinine 1 mg/dl. Calculate eGFR
questions.solution:
Schwartz Formula for eGFR

eGFR= (k*height)/ S. Creatinine

k- Schwartz constant = 0.413

for this patient,

eGFR= (0.413 x 100)/1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73m²

questions.text: Black urine in infants is caused by
questions.solution: • The main clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. The only sign in children is a blackening of the urine on standing, caused by oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid. A history of gray- or black-stained diapers should suggest the diagnosis.

choices.text: Next 5 years or till 18 years of age
Next 5 years or till 25 years of age
Next 10 years or till 18 years of age
Next 5 years or till 40 years of age

questions.text: A 11-year-old child had fever and sore throat 3 weeks back and now presents with fever, arthralgia and raised ESR. His heart evaluation is normal. How long should he receive penicillin prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
The child in the question has Rheumatic fever without carditis. He needs secondary prophylaxis as follows:

Out of the given options, the best answer is a.

questions.text: Transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes microcephaly is?
questions.solution:
• Out of all the options, only Zika virus can be transmitted through mosquitoes.
  • Zika virus infection during pregnancy is a cause of microcephaly and other congenital malformations in the infant, including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities and hearing loss. These clinical features are collectively referred to as congenital Zika syndrome.
  • The risk of congenital malformations following infection in pregnancy remains unknown; an estimated 5-15% of infants born to women infected with Zika virus during pregnancy have evidence of Zika-related complications. Congenital malformations occur following both symptomatic and asymptomatic infection. Zika infection in pregnancy can also cause complications such as fetal loss, stillbirth, and preterm birth.

Reference: https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/zika-virus

questions.text: Which vaccine should I be given every year?
questions.solution:
• Influenza vaccine strains are updated every 6 months. One before monsoon and second before winter.
  • For continued protection to new influenza virus strains, Influenza vaccine is recommended yearly.

questions.text: A 12 year old child while trekking, developed severe hypothermia. He was evaluated in a local hospital where an ECG was performed. ECG revealed a specific alteration in the child. What is the likely abnormality?
questions.solution:
The patient is showing a typical Osborn wave, also called J wave.

  • Osborn wave or J wave is a positive wave seen at the J-point on ECG
  • The J point in the ECG is the point where the QRS complex joins the ST segment.
  • MC seen in hypothermia, but also described in Hypercalcemia, Brugada Syndrome, Myocardial Ischemia

questions.text: A child is a known case of VSD with surgery planned after 3 months. He had 1 episode of severe bronchiolitis last year requiring hospitalization. Now, there is another outbreak of RSV infection in the community. What prophylactic agent you will consider in this child?
questions.solution:
Administration of palivizumab (15 mg/kg IM once a month), a neutralizing humanized murine monoclonal antibody against F-protein of RSV, is recommended for protecting high-risk children against serious complications from RSV disease.

  • Immunoprophylaxis reduces the frequency and totaldays of hospitalization for RSV infections in high-risk infants in about half of cases.
  • Ribavirin is therapeutic, not prophylactic.

questions.text: In which trimester is the Quadruple Test done for Antenatal Screening of Down Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Antenatal Screening for Down syndrome involves

  • 1st Trimester Combined Test: Comprises ultrasound to measure nuchal fold thickness, raised beta-HCG and low levels of PAPP-A
  • 2nd Trimester Triple Test: Comprises Maternal Serum AFP, Unconjugated Estriol (UE3) and Beta-HCG. AFP and UE3 are reduced while Beta-HCG is elevated in Trisomy 21
  • 2nd Trimester Quadruple Test: Triple Test + Increased Inhibin-A levels
  • Integrated test - 1st trimester combined test + 2nd trimester quadruple test

questions.text: Which procedure is being performed in this 2-year-old child who presented with low urine output and serum potassium 7.2 despite medical management?
questions.solution:
Age is a defining factor in dialysis modality selection: 85% of infants and children from birth to 5 yr of age initiate maintenance dialysis treatment using peritoneal dialysis, whereas 50% of children ≥ 13 yr of age initiate maintenance dialysis treatment with hemodialysis.

  • Peritoneal dialysis utilizes the patient's peritoneal membrane to transport fluid and solutes. Excess body water is removed by an osmotic gradient created by the relatively high dextrose concentration in the dialysis fluid; wastes are removed by diffusion from the peritoneal capillaries into the dialysis fluid.
  • Access to the peritoneal cavity is achieved by a surgically inserted, tunneled catheter.
  • Peritoneal dialysis may be provided either as continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (CAPD) or as an automated therapy using a cycler (APD), which allows exchanges of peritoneal fluid to be performed automatically during sleep by a cycler machine. APD is the PD modality of choice in countries without cost restraints.
  • Because peritoneal dialysis is not as efficient as hemodialysis, it must be performed at least 6 times per week.
  • Contraindications to peritoneal dialysis use include anatomic abnormalities (e.g., significant surgical adhesions, omphalocele, gastroschisis, or bladder exstrophy), peritoneal injury (including injury secondary to previous severe peritoneal infections), or lack of an appropriate caregiver.

questions.text: You are called by the newborn nursery nurse secondary to see a 1-day-old infant vomiting with every feed. The patient takes the formula well but vomits large amounts soon after his feed. The emesis is nonbilious. The only significant history is polyhydramnios during his mother's pregnancy. You obtain an abdominal radiograph and find a large, dilated stomach. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
It is a tough question, but such questions can be answered by ruling out other options easily.

  • Option A- Pyloric stenosis is an acquired condition and would NEVER present in the first few days of life, nor would it be associated with a large stomach at birth and polyhydramnios.
  • Option B- Duodenal webs and atresia would likely present with bilious vomiting.
  • Option C- Jejunoileal atresia would also likely present with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension.
  • Option D- Neonates with pyloric atresia will present with early onset of vomiting that is nonbilious, as well as a dilated stomach at birth. The mother may also have polyhydramnios during her pregnancy.

questions.text: Which among the following is correct regarding definition of adolescent period?
questions.solution:
Adolescent period is defined as age group between 10-19 years. The period can further be sub-divided into:

  • Early Adolescent period: 10-13 years
  • Mid Adolescent period: 14-16 years
  • Late Adolescent period: 17-19 years

questions.text: Treatment of choice in NEC Stage IIIB in an ELBW neonate who is extremely unstable and has DIC includes?
questions.solution:
Although Laparotomy with resection of gangrenous bowel and enterostomy formation is the standard procedure in most neonates with Stage IIIB of NEC owing to Perforation, this is not possible in ELBW unstable neonates.

  • Many ELBW neonates who are hemodynamically unstable and/or have complications like uncontrolled DIC cannot undergo immediate surgery.
  • They benefit from PPD- Primary Peritoneal Drainage, till the baby becomes stable & then surgery can be safely followed.

choices.text: Recommend cessation of breast-feeding for 48 hours and supplement with formula
Wait for 6 hours and retest the serum bilirubin level

questions.text: A 30-hour-old full-term infant has facial and chest jaundice. He is breastfeeding well and has an otherwise normal examination. His bilirubin level is 15.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questions.solution:
Ideally decision to start phototherapy or exchange transfusion depends on American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Charts.

Practically, the following cut-offs are often used as a ready reckoner

  • Age 24 hr- Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 10 mg/dl or more
  • Age 48 hr- Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 13 mg/dl or more
  • Age 72 hr- Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 15 mg/dl or more
  • Age 96 hr and beyond- Cut-off of TSB to start PT is 18 mg/dl or more

questions.text: The presentation of a child with severe combined immune deficiency can be as all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Severe Combined Immunodeficiency has a heterogeneous clinical and immunological phenotype, and in many cases the abnormalities are unknown. It can arise from a number of defined molecular defects.

  • Patients can present with failure to thrive, diarrhoea and recurrent opportunistic infections, which can be very severe.
  • Recurrent thrush and skin rashes from viral infections also occur.
  • Interstitial pneumonitis due to opportunistic infections is commonly seen. Pneumocystis carinii, respiratory syncytial virus, cytomegalovirus, adenovirus, influenza and parainfluenza are all responsible for respiratory infections.
  • If BCG is given at birth to these children, they may develop BCG infection. This may have severe consequences, with widespread disease in the lungs, liver, spleen and GIT.
  • Bacterial and fungal pneumonias have also been described, and prognosis is poor if effective measures are not taken early.
  • A bone marrow transplant is the only curative procedure in these cases, and early referral should be made to avoid Enzyme replacement therapy and gene therapy can be used in other types of SCID.

questions.text: A vegan patient with MCV of 110 fl and Hb of 10 gm% is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Clues in the question include low Hb with a high MCV, suggesting macrocytic anaemia.

Furthermore, vegan diet indicates vit b12 deficiency to be likely and thus, the cause is megaloblastic anaemia.

Kindly note that MCV> 100-120 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia.

questions.text: Most common cardiac lesion in down's syndrome is?
questions.solution: Affected individuals with Down Syndrome are more prone to congenital heart defects (50%) such as atrioventricular septal defects, ventricular septal defects, isolated secundum atrial septal defects, patent ductus arteriosus, and tetralogy of Fallot. MC congenital heart disease in down syndrome is endocardial cushion defect, also called as complete AV septal defect or atrioventricular canal defect.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy for the past week. On exam, tonsillar inflammation, palatal petechiae, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly are identified. Which of the following describes the mode of transmission of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, tonsillar enlargement and palatal petechiae, especially at the junction of soft and hard palate suggest a diagnosis of Infectious Mononucleosis, caused by Epstein Barr Virus.

  • Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus and occurs most often in adolescents and young adults. Infectious mononucleosis is transmitted by salivary gland secretions, such as by sharing drinks or kissing.
  • The classic symptoms and signs of infectious mononucleosis include pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, fever, fatigue, and splenomegaly.
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy tends to affect the posterior chain more than the anterior chain.
  • Patients presenting with infectious mononucleosis may also have a rash. The rash has various presentations, including petechial, maculopapular, and urticarial variations, and occurs most often after antibiotics were inadvertently administered due to an incorrect diagnosis, such as streptococcal pharyngitis.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in a child of Kawasaki Disease between 3rd to 6th week of illness?
questions.solution:
Coronary Artery Aneurysms (CAAs) tend to develop between 2nd to 3rd week of illness and thrombosis of these is considered to be the most common cause of death in KD patients.

  • CAAs tend to form in 20-25% of untreated cases, 15% of IVIG-resistant cases and <5% of adequately treated IVIG-responsive cased of KD.
  • Myocarditis is the most common complication of KD but is usually manageable and causes mortality due to CCF only in the early parts of illness if its severe or in the presence of co-existing complications.

questions.text: Look at the image below and tell the approximate age at which this milestone is normally attained in a child?
questions.solution:
As seen in the image, the child is crawling/creeping upstairs, which is normally attained at 15 months of age.

Remember the following milestones related to stair-walking

questions.text: Handedness gets established at what age?
questions.solution:
Handedness develops in a child at 3 years of age, i.e., 36 months of age.

  • As per Nelson, 'Handedness is usually established by the 3rd year. Frustration may result from attempts to change children's hand preference.'

questions.text: A >48-hour neonate has still not passed meconium after birth. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
A water-soluble contrast enema is the investigation of choice in delayed passage of meconium since it is both diagnostic and therapeutic.


  • It can diagnose Hirschsprung disease, meconium ileus, atresias
  • Can also remove meconium plug in meconium plug syndrome and have therapeutic action.

questions.text: A 6-week-old child has just received Pentavalent vaccine today. Components of Pentavalent vaccine shall include?
questions.solution:
Pentavalent vaccines are given according to the National immunization Program at 6-week, 10 week and 14 weeks.

  • It provides protection against 5 vaccine preventable diseases including Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and H. Influenzae type b.
  • Pneumococcal vaccines and Fractional IPV are also administered along with this but are not part of pentavalent vaccine.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with back pain and pain in both ankles and left knee. When he bends forward, his lower spine remains straight. There is localized tenderness around the left foot. Likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ankylosing spondylitis is one of a group of diseases - spondyloarthropathies - which also includes arthritis following inflammatory bowel diseases and chronic reactive arthritis following enteric or genitourinary tract infection.

  • They are characterized by inflammation of the joints and involvement of the axial skeleton.
  • Enthesitis is present and characterized by inflammation at the sites of attachment of ligaments, tendons, fascies and capsules.
  • The diagnosis of a spondyloarthropathy is suggested by onset in an older child with oligoarthritis affecting the hips, knees or ankles and accompanied by enthesitis.
  • Radiographic evidence will help in diagnosing ankylosing spondylitis, and shows evidence of sacroiliitis in the form of extensive sclerosis, erosions of joint margins and apparent widening of the joint space.
  • HLA-B27 occurs in 90% of patients with juvenile ankylosing spondylitis (JAS). The ESR can be high. Iridocyclitis occurs in a quarter of patients with JAS.
  • Controlling pain and minimizing inflammation is the treatment target for these patients.

questions.text: A couple did not have a child for more than 3 years and went for check-up. The check-up of lady was normal but the male was found to have tall limbs, gynecomastia, scant pubic and facial hair as well as small testes. He had history of loud, aggressive and anti-social behaviour in his school days and adolescent period. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tall limbs, gynecomastia, small testes and lack of secondary sexual characters are a feature of Klinefelter Syndrome.

  • Mostly infertile and have frequent behavioural problems
  • IQ is suboptimal to low
  • Patients have hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

choices.text: Breast milk contains more Vitamin K

questions.text: Which of the following is correct comparing breast milk with cow's milk?
questions.solution:
Absolute amount of calcium is less in breast milk than animal milk but since Calcium: Phosphorous Ratio is 2:1, the absorption is better.

Key points to note

  • Vitamins deficient in breast milk: Vit K, Vit D, Vit B1
  • Mineral deficient in breast milk: Fluoride
  • Breast milk has more lactose but less fat, protein, calcium than animal milk
  • Breast milk is rich in Whey protein (better) compared to casein of animal milk. Breast milk also has more Taurine and Cysteine
  • Breast milk has more MUFA, PUFA and especially rich in DHA, i.e. Docosahexaenoic Acid

choices.text: Inj Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart
Inj Betamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart
Inj Dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 12 hours apart
Inj Dexamethasone 12 mg for 2 doses 12 hours apart

questions.text: What is the currently recommended dose of steroids for attaining fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
As per WHO & IAP guidelines, Antenatal Therapy using maternal Dexamethasone is preferred for the prevention of RDS and helping the fetus attain early lung maturity.

  • IAP 2022 Guidelines Say "Dexamethasone is preferred over betamethasone in India as the evidence base for efficacy of betamethasone stems from a mixture of short and longacting salt, which is not available in India. For threatened labor between 240/7 and 336/7 weeks, dexamethasone at a dose of 6 mg intramuscular every 12 hourly for four doses is recommended."
  • Betamethasone is an alternative and when used, the dosage for Betamethasone is 12 mg IM 2 doses 24 hours apart each.

questions.text: Finnish type of congenital nephrotic syndrome arises due to mutations in?
questions.solution:
Mutations in NPHS-1 gene produces an Autosomal Recessive type of Congenital Nephrotic Syndrome called as "Finnish Type". NPHS-1 codes for nephrin protein, a key component of glomerular basement membrane.

Genes implicated in congenital nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. There was also a history of joint pains. There was no mucosal bleeding. Which coagulation factor deficiency can be responsible?
questions.solution:
Mucosal bleed and cutaneous bleeds are more with Platelet defects. Deep tissue bleeding like joint bleed or muscle bleeds are common with clotting factor deficiencies.

  • Hence, best answer among the options with be Factor 8 & 9 deficiency i.e. Hemophilia A and B.

questions.text: Pediatric airway is different from adult in which aspect?
questions.solution:
Features of pediatric airway compared to an adult airway include the following

  • Relatively larger tongue
  • Short epiglottis
  • Larynx is placed higher
  • Subglottic area is the narrowest part
